Project Description: The key objectives of the project will be to assist the Government in: (a) short-term rehabilitation of St. Lucia's hydraulic infrastructure damaged by tropical storm "Debbie"; (b) preparing an integrated watershed management strategy and program; and (c) strengthening institutional capacities in environmental management and flood preparedness. The project would mainly comprise: (a) priority river and drainage works to restore them to operable levels; (b) technical assistance for geomorphological surveys, improving hydrological data collection and analysis, and slope stabilization trials; and (c) technical assistance for the preparation of watershed management plans and pilot projects, and for improving sector institutions. Project Benefits: The main project benefits will be to reduce the probability of future flood damage and to address long term natural resource management problems. The project will introduce a more coherent strategy for land usage in selected catchments. In the short run, the project will help restore presently weakened hydraulic infrastructure in important agricultural areas, enabling their residents to resume disrupted employment more fully. Poverty Category: While the project is not included in the program of targeted poverty interventions, its labor intensive work program will partly offset some of the income lost from the storm's impact. Project Risks: The major project risks concern its timely implementation, as some of its rationale would be vitiated by tardy execution, as the Government lacks experience in managing activities of this type, it is taking suitable steps to put project management on a firm basis from the outset, and to gear up rapidly. Financing Plan: See para. 2.19 Net Present Value: Not Applicable

BACKGROUND Country Setting. 1.1 Saint Lucia is the most populous of the members of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS), with 158,000 current residents. In the 1980s, its real annual growth of gross domestic product (GDP) averaged about seven percent. This strong performance was due to sound economic management (e.g., annual fiscal savings of about ten percent of GDP in 1988-93), expansion of markets for traditional exports, in particular bananas, and increased tourism fueled by foreign investments of over ten percent of GDP. In their wake, the social indicators showed significant improvement. However, based on a poverty profile initiated by the Caribbean Development Bank (CDB) in 1994, there are indications that pockets of poverty exist. 1.2 Saint Lucia has reasonably good prospects for sustainable growth through building on these achievements. But its past steady growth has slowed to less than three percent during the 1990s, largely because of fundamental changes in the external environment. Increased competition from Latin American banana exporters has eroded the country's long standing preferential market arrangements in Western Europe. The initiation in mid-1993 of a more restrictive European Union (EU) banana regime also figured in the recent slippage. In addition, concessional aid flows have declined in the nineties. Social disruptions accompanied the changes in the banana situation during 1993-94. 1.3 These adverse developments were exacerbated by the September 1994 tropical storm "Debbie," which caused unprecedented damage. The resulting losses are estimated to have reduced banana income by the equivalent of seven percent of 1993 GDP. The overall damage to the economy was tentatively calculated at 19 percent of the same. Following these, the lower banana export proceeds coupled with increased imports required for the reconstruction program are projected to widen the gap in external accounts in 1994-95. The Government's projections show that real GDP will significantly decline from an annual average of three percent during the 1990s to lower growth in the short run depending upon the pace of implementation of the reconstruction program. 1.4 The flood damage, therefore, came at a difficult moment, especially as St. Lucia is pursuing much needed economic diversification. The economy has already been undergoing considerable change towards reduced agricultural dependence, with tourism and export services becoming more prominent. However, agricultural diversification has yet to yield substantial benefits, the last few years' construction boom has largely dissipated, and manufacturing activity has turned down. To these ends, the authorities issued a medium term economic strategy document (developed with the Bank) in March 1994; are discussing future banana policy with the EU, UK and the Caribbean Development Bank (CDB); and are examining development options with bilateral assistance, including a program of economic transition that would: (i) restructure the banana industry and wean away inefficient farmers; (ii) provide temporary safety nets for the displaced farmers; and (iii) further develop infrastructure and human resources for services- oriented economy while improving the incentive of regulatory frameworks for broad based growth. 1.5 Saint Lucia's topography is rugged with mountain peaks and deeply incised river channels. Less than ten percent of the total land area occurs on slopes of less than five degrees. Thus the great bulk of land requires some form of soil conservation. In addition, only about six
 -2- percent of all available land is considered prime agricultural soil (Classes 1-111, U.S. Department of Agriculture). 1.6 Agriculture contributed 20 percent of GDP in 1994, more than any other sector. In addition, the 1991 census reflected that it occupied almost a fourth of the labor force, although many farmers are subsistence producers who often have other income sources. Agriculture dominates land usage too (about 55 percent of the island). The last land survey (1989) found forests covering about 35 percent of the land, and settlements most of the balance. However, forest clearance for cultivation has been proceeding rapidly; almost 20 percent of the land was converted to agriculture in 1977-89. Sectoral Issues and Government Strategy 1.7 Land Use. This is influenced by several aspects of the country's property laws, registration practices and by inadequate legislative and institutional capacity. The total land area is 152,320 acres (616 square kilometers) of which 38 percent constitute total farm land. Of the total farm land available, only 2.6 percent is of Class 1, 35 percent correspond to Class II to IV, 11 percent corresponds to forest reserve and the other 51 percent is distributed among grassland, woodlands, rural settlements, urban, commercial, tourism and industrial uses. There are limited flat lands, with less than ten percent of the island having slopes of less than five degrees. This geographic configuration poses physical limitations on the availability of land to meet diverse demands and interests. 1.8 With steep slopes occupying some two thirds of forest areas, the latter's increasing cultivation has been worrying in its stimulation of more intensive farming. So too has the shift towards smaller farms. Between 1973 and 1986, the number of farms grew about six percent while the total cultivated area diminished 19 percent. Farms over 50 acres have comprised less than one percent of the total. Conversely, 92 percent of the farms had 4 or fewer ha, and produced about 60 percent of agricultural output. 1.9 These trends have made for a considerable mismatch between land suitability and its actual use. The 1989 studies performed for the Forest Management Plan showed high or very high conflict between actual and recommended land use on almost seven percent of Saint Lucia, and moderate conflict on about 25 percent. While the overall figures are not alarming, the largest areas in the moderate-very high conflict classes were in the agriculturally important Roseau and Cul de Sac watersheds. Moreover, the areas in the moderate to very high conflict classes are believed to have grown since the 1989 assessment. The Forest Management Plan calls for numerous measures to stem this deterioration, including reforestation activities, intensified extension services in forest buffer zones, and tighter patrolling to prevent encroachment. 1.10 The agricultural land which is intensively farmed is mainly used for monoculture of bananas, sometimes mixed with coconuts or other tree crops. The most concentrated banana production occurs on plantations on flat valley land and adjacent moderately sloping hills. The growing number of small-scale producers mostly farm on steeper, higher land. This is troubling because valley production requires the maintenance of forest cover in the upper watersheds to reduce runoff and erosion. I.11 Agricultural land, as well as towns and roads in valleys, have consequently become more vulnerable to floods, river siltation and sediment flows. Over time, substantial tracts of banana crop, soil cover and forests have been lost. Also, the sustained environmental degradation from the increasing moves to higher slopes has decreased water retention capacity, thereby overtaxing drainage systems. The devegetation of upland areas has caused thousands of tons of silt and sediment to be eroded during rainy periods. Sediment clogs stream channels, causing floods that
 -3- have weakened infrastructure. It also has clouded water and has been choking coral reefs, reducing marine productivity and tourism attractions. 1.12 Furthermore, Saint Lucia suffers from widespread landslides and torrential rains often exceed 150 inches yearly in the interior, causing runoff down sloping parts of catchments. Since the latter are usually small and the slopes relatively steep, the runoff is quite high. Besides these natural problems, Saint Lucia's agricultural development has been constrained by the overall small land area, equally small sized farms, skewed distribution of lands (many without title) and absentee ownership. The sector moreover has been excessively dependent on the output of bananas, the country's most adequate crop. Their exports grew from 84,000 to 132,000 tons in 1987-92. This situation is now jeopardized with the aforementioned narrowing of preferential banana sales arrangements. Under the EU trade regime which became effective in July 1993, St. Lucia will continue to have access to that market for some 127,000 ton banana exports. However, it now confronts increased competition from countries that produce bananas at lower cost and with equal, if not better, quality. Consequently, present developments project further, and sharper, price declines and smaller export revenues. 1.13 The Government has been trying to develop more non-traditional crops for diversifying agriculture. These efforts, ongoing for some time, have had limited success. In part, this has been due to banana production's preferential prices, guaranteed markets, insurance scheme and effective payments systems. The country has also found some agricultural alternatives to be risky, and total non-traditional export earnings averaged only US$1 million p.a. in 1987-92. Therefore the changing circumstances require redoubling these efforts. The Government's recent medium-term economic strategy consequently calls, among others, for increasing the capacity of livestock and fisheries, pursuing more market-oriented diversification approaches, and upgrading distribution and marketing facilities. 1.14 In the interim, the deteriorating banana prospects are apt to alter land use and agricultural employment. Marginal farmers may withdraw from banana production and need other means of livelihood. Some medium and large-scale banana farmers may gradually convert part of their land to growing other cash crops. (Saint Lucia's valley soils, unsuitable for deep-rooting tree crops, could be used for intensive vegetable or cut flower production.) Some large-scale banana farmers will probably seek to increase the efficiency of their production in order to remain competitive. Thus, there could be substantially increased demand for irrigation systems in order to reduce drought impacts. Other requirements would probably include considerably improved extension services, more reliable availability of fertilizers, and greater attention to fruit quality and to timing more banana exports to meet peak European demands. 1.15 Water Use and River Management. The island's water resources are limited with no economic prospects for increases (at present technology); groundwater supply is negligible. Storage of supplies to meet dry season needs and accessing sediment-free water in other months are already major problems; there is frequent rationing. Agriculture has traditionally deserved priority in its water claims. But now with tourism and urban demands growing, it will have to reduce its demands. The Roseau water storage reservoir is scheduled to ensure adequate supply up to year 2025. But it will not serve the growing southern areas. Water resource management, therefore, requires equally high priority, as do considerations of reducing crops' water demands and irrigation. Better watershed management in Saint Lucia needs to take into account that the rivers (which provide most water supplies) are subject to increasing demands. In practice, this means management of the rivers so that they are kept in such shape that they can perform optimally. For these purposes, there needs to be more effective coordination among the several government agencies concerned with development, allocation and regulation of these resources. The proposed project aims to advance this.
 -4- 1.16 Lack of Adequate Information and Instrumentation. Present climatic and hydrological data collection and analysis must be upgraded because they are inadequate for planning resource development. One of the recent experience's lessons was the impossibility of analyzing the flood's magnitude or measuring its impact on inland water because of the paucity of reliable data on rainfall, river levels and stream flow. The few hydrological instruments in place did not function while others were washed away. There are furthermore no records of any length about discharges in any rivers, save for information limited to the Roseau area. Current data moreover only permits speculation as to whether "Debbie"-type storms are prone to recur at average 50 year intervals or more frequently. Thus, the network of meteorological and hydrological stations should be expanded and its equipment upgraded. 1.17 Environmental Concerns. Environmental awareness in Saint Lucia was relatively advanced prior to the storm. Agriculture and tourism have been recognized to be heavily dependent on the use of the country's limited natural resources. The Government encourages attention to environmental issues and, out of these concerns, the authorities have been attacking several environmental problems over the past several years, e.g., commissioning the Rodney Bay (sewerage) and Roseau Dam, and chartering solid waste management activities (the subject of a proposed OECS project that the Bank is now helping prepare). They likewise prepared (with Bank support) the National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP), and with support from several national and regional NGOs a Forestry Management Plan. 1.18 Slope erosion has been termed the "most visibly dramatic conservation issue in Saint Lucia" because thousands of tons of silt and sediment are eroded in the rainy season from deforested upland areas and carried away by enhanced runoff. The sediment clogs stream channels causing floods and infrastructure damage, fills drainage ditches, clouds the water and chokes coral reefs as it finally settles in the sea. Such damage depletes the coastal fisheries dependent upon coral reefs and detracts from the diving experience so important to Saint Lucia's tourism industry. Frequent heavy scouring of rivers and silt accumulation along with loss of rive-edge vegetation have adverse effects on riverine life and biodiversity Water supplies are also affected since natural storage of water in the upper watersheds is reduced by clearing and cultivating hillsides. 1.19 Strategies to reduce the adverse environmental impacts of deforestation and cultivation practices should be an integral element of proposed watershed management initiatives. "Debbie" underscored the need for greater momentum in these fields. The nation was shocked into a greater appreciation of the fragility of its environment and that past practices have posed serious flood hazards to low-lying, heavily populated sections downstream. The storm thus confirmed the NEAP's judgment that "...there still remains much to be done, particularly in the areas of institutional coordination for environmental management..". The proposed project includes measures aimed at such requirements (para. 2.11). 1.20 Disaster Preparedness. Hurricanes, tropical storms and depressions are the most common and damaging natural disasters with potential for severe impacts on the country. Hurricanes usually occur between June and November, with 80 percent of those affecting Saint Lucia occurring between July 15 and October 1. The major causes of damage from hurricanes are flooding from rainfall, coastal flooding, storm waves, landslides and winds. The Government has established an Office of Disaster Preparedness (ODP) to coordinate all preparedness activities with a national network of community groups which can be activated in response to any disaster or emergency. 1.21 Notwithstanding the functions assigned to this office, its capacity needs to be strengthened to minimize the impact of disasters similar to "Debbie" and to provide the population with an effective early warning system. The vulnerability of floodplain areas to flash floods may have
 -5- increased after "Debbie" due to destabilization of soils on slopes in areas where land slips occurred and the silting up of river beds. Thus, preparation of flood hazard mapping in priority watersheds would be supported under the proposed project. It would complement a landslide hazard map currently under preparation by an OAS-funded specialist. Other aspects to be included under the proposed project: arrangements to establish 24-hour operation of the Meteorological Services's forecasting office and radio services when there is risk of heavy rainfall events; improved arrangements for public warnings of the risk of flash floods in towns and villages located in vulnerable floodplain areas; design and establishment of a system to disseminate information regarding location of shelters throughout the island; and developing an improved building code appropriate to the potential natural hazards that affect the country. 1.22 Institutional Aspects. While reportedly there is a substantive body of legal instruments to deal with resource management issues, the main weakness is the lack of adequate environmental focus and the dispersal of responsibility for administering and enforcing existing legislation. In addition, resource management functions are not always clear cut and overlapping of responsibilities is not uncommon. Lack of inter-institutional coordination results in a fragmentation of some key governmental functions such as development control, resource protection and resource development. Presently, forests, banana crops, water supply, fisheries and communities within a watershed are all managed by different entities working in relative isolation from one another but significantly affecting each other's jobs. For a sustainable management effort to be successful, an institutional framework must be created and supported by a multi-sectoral, inter-institutional cooperation plan. 1.23 The main institution within Government which has a role in environmental management is the Ministry of Planning, Development and Environment (MOPDE). The Central Planning Unit of this Ministry is made up of six sections. Even within this Ministry, several of the Sections have varying degrees of responsibility for environmental management and resource coordination. The Government needs to establish an institutional focal point within the Ministry of Planning with a clearly defined and effective role in environmental planning and management. The main functions of this focal point should be to take the lead role in developing/updating national environmental policy, establish coordinating inter-institutional links to carry out policy decisions and ensure consultations within and outside the Government on environmental issues. 1.24 For the proposed project, the immnediate objective would be to establish a temporary institutional mechanism involving the existing entities that have specific sectoral responsibilities in implementing activities under the proposed project. These entities include: the Ministry of Communications, Works and Transport (MOCWT), and the Ministry of Agriculture, Lands, Forestry and Fisheries (MOALFF). However, coordination and responsibility should be assigned to the MOPDE. In addition to these entities, the Government should coordinate its efforts with Non-Governmental Organizations and formal/informal town committees to assure public participation. Tropical Storm "Debbie" 1.25 The uncertainties about the future were enlarged by "Debbie," which, although the hydrologic data is weak, clearly was one of the country's worst storms. It aggravated agricultural areas already saturated by previous rainfall, rerouted channels, scoured banks and deposited thick silt layers. Rivers overflowed their banks, flooding adjacent agricultural land and urban areas. Even protected riverbanks eroded, and bridges and culverts were washed away. Heavy sediment was deposited on the banks and in the river bed, obstructing later normal flows. There were heavy farming losses with about half of banana production acreage affected; 20 percent was severely damaged. Fortunately though, bananas are a resilient crop and there already are signs of some quick recovery.
 -6- 1.26 In addition, the Government speedily and successfully launched emergency relief operations. About 80 percent of water supply was resumed, temporary bridges installed, roads cleared and some river protection works begun. Debris and sediment deposits were removed from urban areas and critical river channel sections, and drainage canals are being cleared of silt. The completion of Roseau Dam (which Loan 3184-SLU and Credit 2120-SLU are assisting) will be delayed but its construction has been resumed. The Overseas Development Agency (ODA) through its Caribbean affiliate, the British Development Division in the Caribbean (BDDC) and the Canadian International Development Association (CIDA) provided timely assistance for these measures, which started to contain and somewhat ameliorate "Debbie's" infrastructural damage. However, these efforts were hampered by additional rains, and further repair work had to await the 1995 dry season. 1.27 However, notwithstanding the storm's considerable direct damage, "Debbie's" main significance was its worsening of the already stressed environment as a consequence of the aforementioned past inappropriate land cultivation practices (ref. paras. 1.8-1.10). One example of the compounded effects has been the greater density after the storm of landslides in deforested slopes than elsewhere. Second, the eroded riverbanks and areas exposed by land slides now need to be stabilized more urgently in order to reduce further large sediment movements into rivers during future rainy seasons. There is now considerably more transportable sediment in the watersheds, some of which will be deposited in river and drainage channels. The attendant river meandering that may be induced could expose bank protection works to heavier scouring. Moreover, the storm's added pressure on natural resources will worsen damage from even much milder future storms. Therefore, all river and drainage works will need much more maintenance in the immediate future, especially to compensate for recent under-investment in such activities. 1.28 Last November, the Government estimated that the reconstruction program would require some US$57 million over the next three years. It reported that only slightly more than half of this sum had then been pledged or identified. As a result, given reduced export earnings and smaller customs revenues, the authorities have been confronting serious fiscal constraints. The Government deferred all capital workcs programmed for 1994-95. In the process too, social hardships have increased, particularly among the many small farmers. Lessening this toll is the immediate objective of the rehabilitation program which the authorities are eager to advance as far as possible during the 1995 dry season. They particularly seek to retrain the rivers affected, clear the blocked drainage, and remove the heavy sedimentation to bring productive activities and the livelihood of the population back to more normal levels. 1.29 The proposed project investments address these problems. Regarding maintenance costs, it is estimated that during the next five years, annual maintenance spending would triple the costs of previous normal years. The incremental recurrent budget expenditures over this period are estimated to total US$7.1 million. These annual expenditures would be included in the annual Project Implementation Plan (para.2.33). Government Strategy 1.30 In the wake of these events, the Government fully understands that "Debbie's" incremental effects have exacerbated the already serious issues in watershed management, and intends to take steps to prevent further expansion of cultivation in the remaining forest areas, and to persuade farmers to abandon their harmful practices. The Government's Forest Management Plan aims, among other things, to expand forest reserves in the upper watersheds and water catchment areas; reforest non-forested areas within forest reserves; strengthen the patrolling of reserve boundaries to prevent encroachment; strengthen wildlife and applied research activities; and strengthen the organizational structure of the Forest and Land Department. The authorities
 -7- particularly appreciate that they lack an appropriate strategy to guide sector policies addressing: (a) the use and protection of somewhat depletable natural resources in sustainable agricultural systems; (b) orchestrating basic changes in land uses by, and income sources of, a sizeable part of the work force; and (c) focusing agricultural practices more on improved productivity rather than on expansion of cultivated areas. 1.31 The Government has, therefore, set the following medium-term targets: (a) to establish development criteria and guidelines and formulate a phased watershed management plan by approximately fall 1995; (b) to put an institutional framework with supporting rules in place by end 1995; (c) to start the first watershed management pilot project in January 1996, followed by the initiation of the first full watershed operation; (d) to introduce land use and watershed regulations and complete the main works in the first full watershed operation by end 1997; and (e) by the end of 2000, achieve reasonable river stabilization in the first full watershed project, and to have introduced and enforced final sector regulations. Lessons from General Bank Experience 1.32 Key lessons from emergency recovery-type activities have been that reconstruction by itself is not enough: measures must be taken to reduce the risk of future disaster damage, and to safeguard people at risk. The proposed operation would help lessen this vulnerability. It also adapts other lessons of past Bank projects of this type, in particular the experience that "fast track" operations, in the interests of quick responses, sometimes overlook important long run concerns. In this connection, the proposed project would address the problems of landslide hazards and concerns of beneficiaries. Further an Operations Evaluation review of water sector projects over two decades was discussed in the Water Resources Management Policy Paper (WRMPP) sent to the Board on April 30,1993. Although it found that there had been relatively few activities in watershed management the latter was an important ingredient in the sustainability of certain (irrigation) projects. The design of this project follows closely the recommendations of the WRMPP. A special characteristic of our approach in the OECS has been the sub- regional approach of our involvement, both through lines of credit channeled through the CDB and for specific regional projects, in view of the relatively high cost of individual operations in such small countries. Over time, CDB has taken over most direct lending operations in infrastructure as well as country based policy dialogue and economic and sector work. However, it should be fully recognized that, because of its relatively small size, the CDB is unlikely to be able to fully replace the Bank in the Caribbean; hence the programs of the two institutions have tended to be delineated along comparative advantages, rather than progressive replacement of one institution by the other. Rationale for Bank Involvement 1.36 The proposed project fully supports the CAS, targeting the natural resource management on which the country's future basically depends. The Government also lacks the technical capacity to prepare and execute programs in this sector, for which the Bank's experience is seen as instrumental. Moreover, the Bank's leadership in shaping these programs and attention to their quality would set the proper framework for subsequent watershed and agricultural investments, which the EU, UK and CDB have indicated they plan to provide. 2. THE PROJECT A. Origin and Concept 2.1 After launching "Debbie" relief and rescue operations, the Government requested the Bank to begin preparing a program to help restore the damaged infrastructure. It likewise stressed the importance of the broader issues discussed in paras. 1.7-1.17: making better use of land and water resources in order to prevent the recurrence of similar damage in the future, as well as to advance the achievement of long-term development goals. Based on this two-fold strategy, the Bank immediately moved to help the authorities organize the proposed project. The initial identification mission took place in October 1994. The Government and the Bank mobilized effective aid coordination arrangements for this effort. BDDC funded the consultants who assisted with project preparation. The Organization of American States (OAS) furnished a landslide hazards expert for this purpose as well. These tasks were completed in December 1994.
 -9- And on January 11, 1995 IDA approved a PPF of US$1.0 million to initiate timely implementation of priority rehabilitation civil works. 2.2 It should be noted that the proposed project has modest objectives regarding the inherent problems. It is not designed to provide complete or optimal protection against the possible recurrence of severe floods. Such protection can only emerge from possible future investments, whose plans and pilot operations this project is intended to make available. B. Objectives 2.3 The proposed project will support three main objectives: (i) to initiate the immediate rehabilitation of the hydraulic infrastructure of priority watersheds from the damage caused by the flooding and landslides. These works are intended to reduce the danger to livelihoods and property. from future flooding; (ii) to address the medium and long term requirements for sustainable watershed development by preparing a Watershed Management Plan which would serve as the basis for more integrated, conservation-minded development of key watersheds; and (iii) to strengthen the Government's capacities in environmental management and flood preparedness. In reaching these objectives the Government will seek the direct participation of the population in the project's activities and also attempt to build greater local capacitv for Saint Lucian professionals to engage in them. C Project Description 2.4 To achieve the above objectives, the proposed project will finance a two-year program consisting of the activities summarized below. Total estimated project cost is US$7.1 million. (a) Execution of priority river and drainage rehabilitation works, together with supervisory engineering services for their implementation. Surveys to develop criteria for future design of improved river wvrks and for hazard rnapping; trials of methods for arresting soil movements; and the installation of modernized equipment and related training for improved hydrological data collection and analysis; (b) Preparation of a plan for integrated watershed development, pilot watershed management projects, and of an institutional development program consistent with the National Environmental Action Plan fbr implementing these plans and projects; and (c) Design of measures for advancing national enviromnental development and disaster preparedness. Rehabilitation Works (Base Costs US$4.98 million) 2.5 This component will deal with the most pressing rehabilitation problems and start enhanced maintenance of Saint Lucia's flood control and drainage infrastructure by carrying out priority works during the 1995 dry season. These are identified as river works, with some river works, with some drainage works, to remove obstructions caused by TSD which could endanger agriculture, infrastructure and livelihoods in the following wet season. These works will largely consist of removing boulders and debris deposited in the river beds, desilting their channels, resectioning river beds to permit safe passage of discharges, and restoring existing or applying new river training and bank protection works.

Appraisal indicated that their design for the most part should be sufficiently straightforward to be completed rapidly. MOCWT would be responsible for implementing this component. PREAMBLE Tropical Storm Debbie (TSD) passed over St. Lucia during the early hours of September 1 0, 1 994, causing extensive damage to the country. Continuous intensive rainfall resulted in widespread flooding, massive landslides, sediment transportation and runoffs. Rivers overflowed their banks, flooding adjacent agricultural land and urban areas, particularly, those situated near the mouth of the rivers. Even protected riverbanks were eroded, threatening roads and private property; bridges and culverts were washed away and sediment was deposited on the banks and in the riverbed, obstructing the natural flow of the river. In the immediate period after the storm, the Government of St. Lucia embarked upon a programme of reconstruction to repair the damage caused by the storm. Part of this programme involves the desilting and retraining of the major rivers. It is imperative that obstructions to river channels be removed during this current dry season January - July, 1 995 to avoid further threat to human life, economic and social infrastructure.  -50- Watershed and Environment Management Project Participation Program Proposal Foreword Participation is increasingly recognized as a necessary part of sustainable development strategies. Experience suggests the benefits of development efforts are more likely to be sustained when the ultimate clients are involved in designing and implementing the work involved. In the case of the Watershed and Environment Management Project, participation is particularly important at various stages. For example, as it has been pointed out in the Preparation Report on the project, clean up works to be effective should be coordinated with landowners' work on farm drainage system. This Report also states that in the future, the most serious issue in watershed management is how to prevent further expansion of cultivation into St. Lucia's remaining forest areas and persuade the farmers cultivating steep hill land to give up practices which cause soil erosion and subsequent flash floods, river siltation, crop and properties' damage and deterioration of land and water quality downstream areas. Indeed, all the efforts of St. Lucia Government would be insufficient without the cooperation of farmers and population living by the riversides. To change some agricultural practices that have proved cause negative impact on flow of rivers will take time, patience and wide participation. Objectives The main objective of the proposed Participation Program is to imnprove the quality of the Watershed and Environment Management Project's design and implementation by systematically incorporating the involved population's views and commitment to its results, and to succeed in some specific objectives such as: (a) to inform farmers and the population in general, about the objectives of the Project; (b) to provide people the opportunity to participate in the implementation of the Project so as to ensure its sustainabiity and maintenance; and (c) to institutionalize within the Government the participatory approach by setting up an appropriate organization to prepare and implement the participation program.
 -51- Activities In accordance to these objectives, the Participation Program would have three main activities: (i) Information; (ii) short term actions to support the ongoing clean up of rivers; and (iii) long-term actions for sustainability and maintenance of the Project. Information Information should have at least two different targets: (i) general population; and (ii) farmers and population by the riversides. In both cases, delivery of information should be clear and simple for a common understanding. (i) Information to the first group would include dissemination of the objectives of the Project, the efforts undertaken by the Government and the importance for the future of the country to maintain rivers' watersheds. A mass media communication campaign might be advisable for this purpose; and (ii) Information to the second group, or beneficiaries of the project, should be more precise and direct, emphasizing the need of their cooperation. Workshops to be held by relevant organizations such as the Banana Growers Association, the National Farmers Association, or other local organizations, are recommended. Short-Term Actions It is important to involve farmers and population living by riverside in the clean up of the rivers. Once they have received relevant information, some direct actions should be organized at local level such as drainage at farm lands; support in the removal of debris and garbage cleaning, for instance. The engineers in charge of the technical aspects of the project can help to select some other actions where the local population might participate. Long-Term Actions The design of these actions should consider the following stages: Oi dissemination of information on the need of the activities promoted; (ii) setting up of consultation mechanisms and sharing of decision making on the actions to be undertaken, (iii) formation of committees of beneficiaries or other kind of organizations at grass root level to be in charge of the works; and (iv) strengthening the ability of these organizations to carry out the works. The following measures are to be considered as part of the long term actions: (i) provision of technical assistance to adopt agricultural practices less damaging to the flow of rivers;
 -52- (ii) reforestation and other forestry activities; (iii) river bank protection; (iv) soil protection programs to prevent erosion and subsequent river siltation; (v) improvement of housing design to reduce risk of flooding; and (vi) avoid dumping garbage in the rivers. Consultation and Incentives Both, short- and long-termn actions to be successful should be the result of consultation with the beneficiaries; provision of some kind of incentives and appreciation to participants should be considered. Workshops or other similar techniques are useful for a quick consultation; NGO's and grass root organizations could be also very helpful in this aspect. Incentives should not be of monetary kind, quite the opposite; they could be in the form of technical assistance; support for demonstrative plots; donation of plants for reforestation; public awards and if possible, improvements to the community to compensate its efforts, are recommended. It is advisable to take into account existent programs and entities to organize consultation and provide incentives. Stakeholders Identification of relevant stakeholders is crucial for the purposes of any participation program. This selection would be determined by the situation and the type of activities to be supported. For example, to change agricultural practices, the National Farmers Association might be a relevant stakeholder. To clean and avoid the disposal of garbage in the rivers, the social clubs or other community level organizations would be best suited for this purpose. Some environmental groups might also get involved in the promotion of participation and disseminating information on the Project. Institutional Frmework The Ministry of Planning has been appointed as general coordinator of the Project with the Ministries of Communication, Works and Transport and Agriculture, Lands, Fisheries and Forestry, in charge of the main works. For the purposes of the Participation Program, the main activities lay in the field of the Ministry of Agriculture; however, some ministries such as Education and Labor, Health and Local Government and Youth, Community Development, Social Affairs, Sports and Operatives, might also have a supportive role.
 -53- However, the experience of these ministries in a programn of participation is not clear, therefore, the most suitable entity to be responsible for the preparation and implementation of the program should be selected. It was suggested by the Ministry of Planning that a Committee at the ministerial level might be appointed to deal with participation. The set up of this Committee would be an important step and prove of Government's commitment to the participation program. Nevertheless, a more operational organization might be necessary to promote, organize and monitor the Participation Program. The design of this organization to be in charge of the program, its functions and identification of its human resources and financial needs must receive special attention during preparation ofthe Participation Program. Managers and policy makers in St. Lucia have to be involved in this process. It would be advisable to appoint a team of technicians and social scientists from the different ministries implicated to carry out the various activities of the Program and to take the leading role in its implementation. Pilot Effort The long-term actions intended for sustainability and maintenance of the Project might prove difficult to undertake at a national level at a first stage. Furthermore, some of these activities would possibly need some kind of adjustment to improve results. Therefore, it is recommended to start with a pilot effort before a generalized set up is established. This pilot effort could be initiated in Roseau and Cul de Sac, both places seriously damaged by Debbie and where some traditional agricultural practices actually endanger the sustainability and maintenance of the project. Existing programs within the Government, private institutions and NGO's, related to the participation program's activities should be incorporated to this effort to profit from their experience and practices. Schedule of Preparation The schedule to prepare the Participation Program should be coordinated with the preparation of the Watershed and Environment Management Project in order to support its objectives, therefore, careful timing is important. The following aspects and dates should be considered: (a) Agreement on terms of reference, budget and appointment of consultant(s) and/or members of the Government for the preparation of the Participation Program should be ready by March 1995; (b) A first draft on the campaign for general information purposes should be prepared in April or as soon as an agreement is reached on terms of reference;
 -54- (c) The Participation Program should be ready in three months, on time to be integrated into the Management Plan. Therefore, preparation should begin by March-April and end by June-July; (d) The pilot effort should begin as soon as possible and have some results as feed back after three months of initiated. The expected findings should include factors of success and constrains in implementation; and (e) A monitoring system would be set up and kept during a period of two years to document on advances and problems of the Program every six months, enough to have some results on the expected objectives. Preparation To attain to the proposed schedule, it is suggested a full-time team be appointed to prepare the Program. A consultant with social background and experience in participation or social development should be hired to coordinate the team, concentrate infornation and prepare the final Program. Government's officials forming part of the team should be conunitted to the Program and disseminate their experiences within Government's entities to institutionalize the participatory approach.

doc.abstracts: The Watershed and Environmental Management Project will: (i) initiate the immediate rehabilitation of the hydraulic infrastructure of priority watersheds from the damage caused by the flooding and landslides. These works are intended to reduce the danger to livelihoods and property from future flooding; (ii) address the medium and long term requirements for sustainable watershed development by preparing a Watershed Management Plan which will serve as the basis for more integrated, conservation-minded development of key watersheds; and (iii) strengthen the Government's capacities in environmental management and flood preparedness. Hence, the Government will seek the direct participation of the population in the project's activities and also attempt to build greater local capacity of Saint Lucian professionals to engage in them.
